title: Staff at Titanic shipyard Harland and Wolff cheer as they return to work
text:
Harland and Wolff employees have gone back to work after the closure-threatened shipyard was sold.

There were cheers as the remaining staff walked through the gates in Belfast at 9am.

Workers launched a campaign after the shipyard was placed into administration over the summer.

Jobs saved: Harland and Wolff employees return to work at the Belfast shipyard

A nine-week protest saw them occupy the historic site where the Titanic was built around the clock.

They claimed victory earlier this week when it was announced a buyer had been found.

Harland and Wolff has been bought for £6million by Infrastrata, a London-based company that specialises in energy infrastructure projects.

Steelworker and GMB shop steward Barry Reid described Thursday morning at the shipyard gates as ‘the day we prayed would come’.

Joe Passmore, steelworker and Unite shop steward, said: ‘Let’s get back to work.’
description: Workers launched a nine week campaign after the shipyard was placed into administration over the summer. It saw them occupy the historic site where Titanic was built round-the-clock.
